As someone who was born and raised in Qatar, AND has literally been to the industrial area on foot. I can confirm that most of this is quite common knowledge. Most people are aware of the fact that these labour workers or labourers are treated quite harshly with abysmal working conditions. The footage you've collected is quite accurate and it's impossible not to notice living there. Every where you go, you could see them working on the side of the road and on buildings wearing the uniforms even in the heat. There are a lot of parts of the city, especially industrial area where you have huge labour camps. But the thing is, it's so normalisied that it doesn't really stand out or seen as that big of a problem. It's sort of just accepted. This is the case for most gulf countries, where you have a huge portion of the labour class essentially just segregated, and the kafala system is a rapant problem and a huge human rights issue across the region. Qatar has a huge immigrant population, mainly to reach it's 2030 goal and vision for the future. Seeing as most of the infrastructure for those projects have already been completed, it's a bit too late. The damage has been done. The fact that Qatar is an incredibly rich country and could've easily paid these workers fair wages yet they chose to actively exploit them for as cheap as possible baffles me.

Hey Johnny,

Your reporting is very accurate, yet still disingenuous. You must say that this happens in all of the GCC countries all together and not a special case for Qatar: Saudi Arabia, Emirates, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, even in some other places near them also have the same state of affairs for tens of years ever since discovering hydrocarbons there. You must also say that the construction business, specifically, is ones of the most lethal jobs world wide, not only in that place, but in many other places in Africa, Asia, South America, even the US and Canada for undocumented immigrants and people in need for "any job they can have". You must also say that those construction contractors are European and American companies and they are after maximizing their profits, just like the Qataris. Here in Quebec, we were told in an official training that "we more people in Quebec's construction than any other profession here!" and that is Quebec in Canada of North America!

I would even take it a step further, those workers coming from humble backgrounds are already suffering poverty and harsh life conditions at their own country and their governments: their live conditions are directly influenced by negligence and corruption there. When many go to the very harsh and unspeakable working condition at the GCC countries, and this deeply disheartens me, are at an UPGRADE of their original lifestyles! Hands down they are not treated good. Hands down they deserve to be treated better. But if the World Cup thing has done nothing but to force the laws in those places to change for the better, then it is a HUGE human value already.

I have worked, firsthand, under the Kafala system; to be completely overlooked by a local sponsor. It is a very unjust system and needs reform, the least to say, if not abolished at all. But I have also seen how it is becoming looser and looser and how it is getting re-organized to better benefit the workers. I hope to see it dissolve altogether with no coming back.

Wanna a scoop? OK. See those workers protests "quashed" by the Qatari police? I have a firsthand account from an eye witness who said that the reinforcements to the police came from the American military base there; Al Udeid Air Base. Have a good night sleep Johnny!

Just a tip. Weird zoning is due to the country not actually having street names or building numbers until 2015 or so, and labor camps exist also in Alkhor, Wakra, Dukhan, and so many more areas. The industrial area just has more industrial shops. The metro lines didn’t reach any of the outskirts of Doha due to shortage of time, not because they were intentionally cutting industrial area off.

World Cup construction stadiums were handled by French, Chinese, Turkish, and Italian companies who were contracted to do this. governments don’t send people to recruit, there aren’t enough Qataris to do this job, there were recruitment agencies to recruit labor for this. Yes Qatar with its lack of laws to protect the rights of those workers is at fault, but if this is about human rights, the main perpetrators should at least get an honorable mention. 

Lastly, just an FYI, Qataris don’t get an allowance for just being Qatari, and the older generations did do a lot of these hard labor jobs. My paternal grandfather was Qatari, he was a working in one of those low paying jobs, and he died on duty.

Ok, I'll put it as short as I can but feel free to comment on this. I'm an educated journalist and PR pro, I work at the university teaching journalist, PR and media students. I admire what Johnny has been doing. I agree journalism should be free and with no strings attached to report on what is really going on around us. However, it seems to me Johnny is becoming more and more personal about every single issue he is covering. It is called a personal bias, guilding the lily so to say. I get it: personal insight is an engaging thing for all us viewers but his approach is becoming less and less different from the strings the news corporations and their sponsors or politics attach to them. Less personal attachment and more balance may only contribute to the fairness of the coverage. And more of his material (especially the latest one about FIFA) is becoming chaotic, poorer in research and background story etc. Sorry to say that but try not moving forward in the current direction and get less sit-of-the pants view in favour of a more balanced and truthful coverage with less emotional approach. Stick to information and abandon commentary as much as you can. Please consider it because your golden and I love your coverage I'm sure we need you. Do your job but engage personally a bit less. I know many of you are going to hate me for what I've posted but for the sake of good, fair and real journalism with a capital J, please consider my view

Devil’s Advocate here— how is this different than undocumented South American workers in 🇺🇸? They live in fear of being deported, do manual labor that 🇺🇸 citizens think is beneath them, are paid lower wages, live in large groups because they can’t afford housing on their own, have to pay fees to traffickers that smuggled them to 🇺🇸, some of them die horrible deaths in the back of trucks in transit to 🇺🇸, and I’m sure they’re threatened with deportation either explicitly or implicitly by their bosses. I’m sorry, but it’s difficult to take the moral highground against Qatar’s immigrant labor practices, what they’re doing is just a different flavor of what we do in our country.

I lived in the family zones. It's cool AF. We partied at Pearl Qatar and everything. Having said that, there is truth to your story, but also, it's voluntary. Let me explain. When a job is offered, the workers know the salary expectation and conditions. They don't know that their passports will be taken away and they need an exit visa. Anyway, It's not the Qatar government directly doing this. It's a bunch of shark companies and agents who do this. For instance. The Experts who design the stadiums and conduct feasibility studies are also foreign. They live a good life and enjoy it. Once the construction tender is issued, companies Bid and by so doing, the lowest bidder with the right technical qualifications wins. These companies then go and source cheap labour to complete the won bids. These construction companies go on overdrive to squeeze the workers to make profits. It's not the government. everything is governed by paperwork so it's really voluntary. that's the truth.

There is a mantra that works in the vast majority of investigations of this type

follow the money, follow the money, follow the money...

Who are the construction companies that carry out all the works to adapt the host city of the World Cup within the standards defined by FIFA?

What political manifestations took place during these works, what were their agendas and claims?

What laws were passed within the host country that harm the poorest and those with less power and prestige within a society and who gains more power, money, prestige and recognition from these decisions?

Look what happened in the last cups.

Look at corruption allegations

See the story.
Does it repeat? What patterns exist and repeat?

In the Brazil Cup for example:

How did the government try to hide poverty and the undesirables from the eyes of the world?

Which groups were persecuted?

What were the demonstrations and who were the demonstrators, their agendas and demands?

What was voted in congress during this World Cup period that the big newspapers didn't report?

What were the allegations of corruption that were investigated?

Which corruption schemes will we never know because we don't have the information we need to know what to look for?

Which "winners" became "losers" during power struggles during this event and shortly thereafter?

Politicians, businessmen, workers, institutions?

What can these people tell you about the corruption schemes they were expelled from?

Who or what people were scapegoated in the investigations?

Are they alive?

Can they give interviews?

It's really hard what's going on.

What we can see are just the symptoms of a reaction to an action, just like it happens in the ill  human body.

People working under these conditions are the weakest link, they are the exploited and oppressed.

Who are the rich and oppressors?

What are their interests?

Which status quo modes are maintained?

And what is discarded and transformed during disputes?

Who wins what?

Money, prestige and most of all power...

Who are the victors who come out of these disputed arenas with more power, money and prestige?

Who are the losers?

What can they tell us? Can they talk?
If they can't, why can't they?

Look at FIFA itself.
What corruption schemes and allegations were instigated around the world?

What were the results of these investigations?

What investigations came to nothing?

Who were the people with the power to embargo and hinder these investigations?

Who wins what?

Who loses what?

Who can speak?
Who can't?

Who can manifest?
And who can't?

What is allowed?
What is not allowed?

Bread and Circus.

What's sadder is that when you're a family member of a migrant worker from the Gulf region, you're told that these ridiculous working conditions are normal. You're forced to be desensitized by your own government, recruiting agencies, and your own family for the sake of getting money in. My clan has a long history of being a migrant worker in various countries all over the globe, which is a norm from where I'm from, and we're told from a young age that the Gulf region is where the big bucks are. They also told me stories of their own experiences and how those things shouldn't deter us from working there. My uncles would tell stories about getting slapped in the face in front of his colleagues for simple things, just because of their ethnicity. My aunts would tell stories about being in so much debt because she maxed out her cards in order to send money to her family because her employers refused to give her salary. But this was from the mid-90s to late 2000s

We, from the younger generation, kept asking them why they kept working those conditions and they said that they needed to shut up and endure it, otherwise we wouldn't be able to "enjoy" a comfortable life. Ten years later, we're still not as comfortable as what they're saying.

I grew up in Bangladesh and I'm a software developer in the US now but as a kid, I used to hear from my parents about this issue, how the poor people from villages got trapped into this modern day slavery. All the skyscrapers you see are built by Filipino, African, Indian, Bangladeshi slaves. One of Indian friend's dad was an engineer there and they're considered 2nd class citizens. They have more rights than the slave class but they're still seen as "inferior". I've heard from him how his dad disagreed with one of the Emiratis once and he got spit on. Keep in mind, he was an engineer and not a labor which makes you wonder what would happen to lower class worker. I really wanted Johnny to cover this subject because of the reach his audience gets and his production quality. What a horrible system that I'm sure is pretty common all over the world. I know I saw it in South Korea when I was in the military in the 90's...most of the ladies that worked in the bars around the bases were from other countries (ie Philippines), they were promised to work in a respectful entertainment-type tourism job (lied to) and instead got their passports taken when they arrived and worked in crappy bars serving drinks to nearby military base personnel for a long multi-year contract. Johnny, we have an identical system, with all its components, in Canada for farm workers and other industrial work. In Canada ... recruiters are often gangs in country of origin, recruitment fees, debt required, closed work contract, horrible conditions, death, deportation if you speak out, extortion at home of your pay. It’s called the Temporary Foreign Worker Program and its where Qatar learned its system.  If you want to tell this story I can introduce you to all of the relevant contacts - workers, farm access, rights organizers, lawyers, etc.

@Bulldozer  If you wish to make the claim that I am being disingenuous you should provide clear examples of the differences in immigration programs. 

Please provide comparison examples. Choose two topics
- recruiting tactics 
- worker indebtedness
- poor working conditions, safety issues
- segregation 
- closed work contracts, no negotiating power
- wage theft
- trafficking 
- deportation for speaking up
- no pathway to citizenship, 
- no benefits of residents (health, employment insurance, etc.)

It is not an argument that these things happen to a greater degree in Qatar. If they are also happening in Canada, even to a lesser extent, than they are features of the immigration program. Also, a lot of what happens to a worker in Canada happens in their country of origin, before or after arrival. This offshoring of responsibility and oversight does not mean it is not happening in Canada. It means that the program has found an ingenious way from hiding it from the host public. Worker discipline and exploitation happens in the shadows of these kind of narratives. If the labor crosses borders, your analysis of their entire experience must also. The Canadian government is certainly aware of these problems. They shifted from bilateral agreements with States to privatization through agencies and the exploitation exploded. They are aware of this exploitation - extortion, fees, threats, favoritism, et al - the public should be also. Were you aware? 

I also want to point out that I never equated Qatar and Canada in quantifiable ways... I don’t have hard stats on Qatar. It appears nobody has them. All we have are interviews and minor NGO investigations. There really is no way for us to have an accurate side by side, per capita worker harm analysis. I simply said we have the same system with all its components and features of exploitation. This can be verified. I’m not being disingenuous by pointing out that our immigration systems operate by the same logics.

Coming from Singapore (9:27-9:29 😀🇸🇬), our construction sector is also based on labourers from Bangladesh & India (but not Nepal 🤔). Our labour regulations have also made it difficult (though not impossible) for foreign construction workers to change employers.

I don't know if this is this is the case in Qatar, but I've heard the argument-from an employee of a local NGO advocating foreign workers' rights, no less-that local construction firms fork out quite a bit to recruit and fly in their Bangladeshi & Indian employees, so it is a bit unfair to them when those employees jump ship without completing their contract.

That's debt bondage, it's not illegal or quite a violation of human rights, but it's still iffy. Do you think all the workers who signed the contracts fully understood what they were agreeing to and everything that that entails?

I understand that Singapore cannot only rely on local workers to build the country, because it's so small, but that's where the government should sweep in with tighter labour laws to regulate the excesses of the industry. Being "business friendly" is often not compatible with having fair laws that protect workers.

Edit to add: I think people should be free to pursue happiness, whether by looking for better employment or moving countries to pursue said happiness. But nothing should force them to stay under one employer. The director of a zoo in Stuttgart (where I live) told us in a tour that they don't cage most of the animals because if the animals want to run away, it means the zoo is not doing a good job taking care of them. I don't want to compare people to animals, but I think companies should think like this too. If you have to build a metaphorical cage to keep your workers, maybe your company is not doing a good job taking care of them.

In retrospect that twist was foreshadowed as far back as the moment we meet "Tyr". 

First, when Atreus mentioned him having a spear in the prophecy Odin called it a walking stick. He saw it as an insult because he's old and he thought Atreus saw him as weak, and his pride slipped out. 

Then there was when he suddenly accepted Brok's challenge to making better soup out of the blue. Tyr acted so unmotivated the whole game but the fact that a dwarf did something better made Odin break character in that moment. 

Of course there was Tyr being absent during the whole Garm fiasco. 

As to why he suddenly revealed himself in that moment it was simply his hatred towards a being he deemed lower than him calling him out. His temper finally broke because arrogance is the common trait of gods like him.  Unfortunately, Brok paid the price. I guess if one of the main cast had to die, he or Sindri would thematically make the most sense since they were the first real friends we made on this journey. Hopefully we don't lose anyone else in the finale.

@Cheshire Duke not really. it is harsh but not inhuman. someone choosing to move to a city to earn more but can only perform unskilled jobs can only afford cramped, possibly unhygienic living conditions, a long commute, etc. however they do that to fund the rest of their family who lives in a rural area with limited opportunities. if they manage to make it (relatively) big, they rent an apartment, bring their family over, etc. others move to cities to study, in which case they have a much better footing, as university education is highly subsidized. it is very rigorous though - there would be no time for a part time job, so they would be dependent on unorganized loans (from family/possibly even loan sharks!). they would usually start off renting in a cheap and small but still relatively hygienic apartment, they might choose to marry someone from the city or (more commonly) marry someone from their home town and bring them over to the city, starting a family there. they might even bring siblings/relatives to the city to study and find work - once someone from the family has found a stable footing in an urban area, they usually do their best to bring others and spread the benefits.

Kafala system is not a trap. My father had a kafala bond with a contract as an engineer. He could leave the job but had to leave the country (like work permit in western countries). He could ask to change job but had to first leave and return on a different permit.

Kafala isn't ideal of course , but it never felt as a trap for us..

A lot of this is common knowledge to me, but I did grow up in Saudi Arabia as an expat, so it was just how it was, there wasn't any effort to hide it from us, they didn't stop the workers talking to us if they worked in our compounds (expatriate living communities). The Middle East has had this system for decades at this point, they only want to hide it because the world is watching, but as soon as the World Cup is over, most people will return to apathy.

I'm not saying you shouldn't care, but like BLM, like Asian hate crimes in America, posting social media support messages and marching really accomplishes nothing, and actual change inducing actions is too hard and time consuming for almost every human.

If you want to change things, change then with the power you actually have. If you can vote, vote in every election, if you don't support places like Qatar, don't visit, don't buy their products (Qatar Air flights, PSG memorabilia), if you don't like how a company treats it's employees, don't buy from that company. It's all tiny actions, but they all add up, just look at Twitter and employees/advertisers bailing.

Almost everywhere in the world, labor workers are used.

Take Apple Inc for example. Apple employees design the products. Who do you think make the products? Labor workers.

Same thing happens in every industry. Look at fashion. Designers design the clothes, labor workers make the clothes.

All these businesses hire companies (Usually Asian companies) to do the labor work. The workers are all working under poor constructions.

Only thing US gets away with, is thats they don’t have to import these workers to do the job. They can work from their own countries.

Meanwhile something like construction on a big scale requires making deal with such companies and bring their workers here.

What I’m trying to say is, everyone around the world has to use labor work. It’s not fair, but that is the sad reality. It is however unfair to only single out Qatar and make it as if this problem is exclusive to them only.

Kuwait does the same thing for labor. They call them "Third Country Nationals" the bring in Filipino and Indian and Pakistani people to work and they live in these giant apartment buildings and do all the lower paying jobs but aren't citizens. Typically they are segregated with Filipino people doing more inside type lower level work and Pakistanis doing more construction and outside work. They have no rights. The employers hold their passports and do not give them access to it. I was a US soldier in Iraq who had gone to Kuwait and had a bus driver who was Pakistani. He accidentally cut off a driver and the Kuwaiti man pulled in front of us and blocked us. Opened the bus door and started beating the man. We intervened and he spit on me and left. We reported it to the police and the man was brought in and arrested and was hit. I asked why they were hitting him and what kind of trouble he was in for assaulting the bus driver. The policeman reply was "oh he is not being arrested for that. The man he hit has no rights he is a Pakistani. He is being arrested and beaten for spotting on you American military men. You are guests if the government and this man insulted the government by spitting on you." So beat the hell out of a man for nothing and you are golden because he is from Pakistan, but spit on an American soldier and you get beaten and jailed. Got it. It turned my stomach, but as a visitor to their country and being told by the US Government not to interfere with local laws and rules when we landed I couldn't do anything other than tell them I didn't think it was right.

This is abjectly horrible. However, this also really just seems like the American capitalist model in microcosm, absent the few token labor protections that remain. There is no geographic or social mobility for the working poor here, and little occupational mobility. They work in hazardous service occupations for little pay and are subject to the whims of employers that would deny them healthcare and skirt labor protections wherever possible to increase profits. They often live in overcrowded, squalid conditions.

Qatar’s labor importation system is horrible, obviously. However, it just seems to me like a more obvious, less dressed-up twist on America’s system of economic exploitation.

Thank you for the informative and detailed video. Whereas I was aware that there is funny business going on in Qatar, being aware of something and knowing the details is very different, yet knowing doesn't change the outcome. This ultimately brings me to my point. Just like you state in your closing line, it's very likely that people will forget about all of this, and look elsewhere, onto the next big thing.
Looking at things logically, it is possible that Qatar will temporarily follow through with their promises but then go back to the modern slavery system once the international attention shifts elsewhere. The everyday folk, even if banded together, don't have the power and influence needed to see actual change. What's most likely to occur should go like this:
- The world cup passes, Qatar still in the spotlight
- Some well-intentioned people will try to get justice for the forced laborers, but the Qatar government will at that point start using bribes and business deals to keep these people quiet. If that doesn't work, then the higher ups of the justice seekers will get bribed, and the justice seekers will either drop the matter, or lose their jobs and try to shed light on the matter.
- The rich and the influential won't really care enough to play heroes, unless there is tangible benefits to be had.
- Regardless of how the events progress, eventually the international audience will look elsewhere. Then, the cycle of exploitation will continue.

TLDR: People are hypocritical, it's just that everyone's hypocrisy is to a different degree. People might say things like "this is wrong, do the morally correct thing", but how many are actually willing to dedicate their own time, money and effort for a matter that most likely has no personal effect on them?
As for the people that are affected, it's all poor village families. From any governmental POV, it is not cost effective to actually pursue the matter. Even if the families of the victims manage to group together, they will at most perform a few protests, without any actual results.

My point is, how many of the viewers here actually care about matters that have no effect on you? I might be fatalistic in my way of thinking, but honestly, so many events in history have concluded in a similar manner already.

Johnny, I love the stories you pick to tell and you're obviously talented at editing and creatively organizing your stories. I've thoroughly enjoyed your videos overall with how you handle the facts while not shying away from serious problems that arise in your study of the subject. This story is no different, thank you for working hard to bring it to light. If I may be so bold as to offer an opinion; as cool and fascinating as your creative process genuinely is, it's a little rough to wade through 17min of setup before finally getting to the meat of the story and the main reason I wanted to watch. It felt very much like a "how to get the story" rather than a "Here is the story" which may not have been your intent. Maybe just giving a quick blurb stating that it was very difficult to put this one together and if we're super interested in your personal journey we can watch a seperate video that digs into that aspect? Still a fan either way.
@Johnny Harris Thanks for the reply! Those are some solid reasons to make the choices you did. Happy Thanksgiving!
@Alic4444 Oh man, I hope I don't sound like I'm questioning the very real danger or Johnny's journalistic integrity. I apologize if that sentiment came across in any way.

Also, the beautiful thing is that if you suspect getting stories like this isn't at times dangerous, and the people making this are lying or over dramaticizing the danger, you can always film yourself making the same sort of documentary, adding to the amount of truth available online, while showing how the danger and difficulty aren't actually real.

I think there's a simple point to showing the process that might be easy to miss. The level of difficulty of bringing light to ANYTHING happening in the world that others with power are trying to keep shrouded in secrecy, whether you're talking about Qatar, the US, or anywhere, is itself a revealing experience to show people. Just the amount of red tape, and the danger involved, says something about the world.
Agree. Definitely milking the vid. Entertaining either way.  Side note: do people not realise this happens all around the world?

thanks for the feedback. for this video I decided to document the experience 1. because I thought the format could help people connect with the content of the story (turns out people love to follow the ups and downs of a personal narrative more than to follow the arc of a bunch of information like I usually do) 2. because the difficulty of the journey was also a pillar of evidence showing how severe the qatari police state is and 3. the buttoned up taking head format is kinda getting old to me. I want to be more than information delivery system and help give people an insight in the methods and approaches of the type of journalism we're attempting to do.
True. It could have been ten minutes long. I think there's some advantage if videos are over 30 minutes long, too.

This is excellent journalism from the entire team, but I urge you to look further into this story.
As much as we would like to believe that steps are being taken to improve the conditions of expat workers, they will not be able or allowed to integrate into those societies as they currently are.
My parents were expats (in one of the GCC neighbors of Qatar) for 30+ years now and I was born an expat.
Now I'm 29 years old and an engineer in the same country and I have to work with a lot of laborers and expat workers. A lot of them are my good friends who have invited me to their places of residence as I helped them out in various ways that I possibly can.
After visiting the labor camps & dorms where they live, most of the people just want to get their debts back home cleared, earn money for their marriages or family, and are yearning to get back home. Facilities & amenities are provided, but it's not enough for the sheer number of people in these camps. A lot of these companies running the camps are just looking to make their pockets fatter by overcrowding and under-providing.
But at the same time, some people find it difficult to integrate themselves into society or "family zones". When you live in an authoritarian country, you have no choice but to follow the laws and rules of the same country. If its no alcohol in public places, then you mustn't drink in public places. Chewing tobacco which is quite common in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh is illegal here. But they cannot go without it, and they find it in places where it is sold illegally. Such small things which might be okay to do back home, are considered illegal in these countries. If you are caught, then that's the end of your life here (I've seen it go in more ways than one!).

Please don't let these stories disappear. There are much deeper humanitarian issues here.

As some have mentioned, this is common throughout the rich Gulf countries. However, having spent some time as a white collar expat in both Qatar and the UAE, from my limited perspective things seemed to be worse in Qatar.

In general and from my limited perspective, Emiratis were much nicer people than Qataris. I saw Qataris being very unpleasant towards these workers and were indifferent/arrogant towards expats. I never saw Emiratis being unpleasant towards workers and they were very nice and hospitable towards me. 

Also, in UAE there are malls that are geared towards Emiratis and malls geared towards workers. Some of the workers' malls are nicer than many malls in the US, so at face value the workers seem to be recognized a bit more as an integral part of their economy and country.

Granted, none of this is representative of what happens behind the scenes in UAE but I believe that it is a clue to the fact that it is much better for workers than Qatar.

In both countries there are many places euphemistically termed 'family only' or 'bachelors not allowed'. On face value not wanting somewhere to be inundated with single men and allow more freedom to females may seem nice. Until you realise, a rich single man (especially European/White or local) would never be turned away. And most people on workers' visa cannot sponsor their family and so are permanently excluded.

From India my perspective. Shameful for me that my country's citizens have to work there. Yes many muslims opt for these countries like qatar thinking that it's a islamic country so they will have better future there. I'm not saying hindus or other religion people don't go there. But more than that it's my country failure to provide them the work and providing proper information to the workers. I hope in future we will be able to provide them the jobs here or at least train them better so that they rather go to a better country like europe etc.

Nice vid but you've mixed up some things and i'd like to clarify it.

*Kafeel is basically a citizen/company thats reponsible for employee actions and required to provide life needs for free such as food and home. Companies mostly abuse and treat employees. However normal citizen literally build strong relationships with their employees.

What you been explaining is kafala system being abused and its illegal. It happens even in Kuwait/UAE/KSA
Kafala system is basically, you get residence as long as you work for a citizen/company. If you do not have a kafeel you're not allowed to stay in country. However government gives you 1-3months duration to leave the country or find a new kafeel.

The way certain companies abuse it is they go to poor countries advertise that for X amount of money they can hire them to work in Doha for much higher than what they actually get. However what some employees doesn't notice is they sign in for working for X years or pay X money to cancel the internship and with a bit of corruption those companies sign contracts with the government.

I do not agree nor support their working environment nor the way they being treated. I think its inhuman.

TL:DR: Certain companies abuse kafeel system and with a bit of corruption here n there the get to sign contracts with government. What we've seen in video is not an actual kafeel system its basically human trafficking.

It's not the first time 
and probably won't 
be the last that I'm 
talking about the expatriate
 workers in the Arabian Gulf, 
if you want to hate the authoritarian ruling families.  Do what you want. In fact, as a citizen of the Arab Gulf seeks democratic rule, I will be grateful to you for this.  But these governments in the past years, have changed a lot of laws in order to address the abuse of labor by private companies and supervisors ,Such as canceling the (kfalati) law in which the worker is linked to the citizen, and enacting a law that strictly prohibits the work of workers in the sun at a temperature of 50 degrees Celsius, and enacting a law that prevents taking the passport from the worker.  (And by the way, these supervisors come from the same countries as the workers)  So far, no one wants to talk about these laws or suggest realistic laws that are better for these workers when talking about this issue.   And no one wants to talk about the responsible developing countries from which these workers and managers come ,  And about the labor recruitment companies registered in these developing countries that steal these workers in order to come to the Arabian Gulf,  And about the responsibility of these developing countries, at least, to prevent the arrival of these workers if these countries are really so bad,  So far, no one wants to talk about this issue with fairness and justice , By the way, if these labor contracts were to be called slavery, then a third of the labor contracts are not only in the Third World, but the whole world is slavery.

The size of the pile has become just too damn large and to distinguage between something acceptable and not has been blurred way too much. We've been beaten with bad news now for decades; from war to draught and starvation to enviromental mishaps, companies screwing us over, etc etc, the list goes on (and the LIST goes on.... and on... and on). So to protect our own personal sanity we shut ourselves off of it all: people see the news, but they hardly SEE the news, what it actually means, what the essence of the story entails.

Because of that pushing the the far reaches of our mind of these bad, bad reports people slowly get stressed, panic, get mental and by the help they get from professionals they get to hear that it might be something like an early youthtrauma or stress from work, tentions from the family.. but never: "yes, this world is not going to poop, it already has".
Many, many, many people still try to keep up their mask of that they're so happy and fullfilled with all their new shiny stuff, "succes in life" and happy photo's, but... in many cases they're quite unhappy and sometimes even quite... dead inside.

One last thing then.... we in the west prize ourself RICH. Clean water, sewer system, electricity, dentists, internet, supermarkets, nice car.. eeeeverything no? but when i see in documentaries people from poor regions of our planet, though they can still manige...... shine with inner happyness, I also see the poverties of the western spirit.
And no.. I do not mean every person, but in general. There IS a big gap people, there IS somethign we just..... lost.

Throughout the whole video, the word “coolie” keeps coming up in my mind. The forced labor/slaves you talk about here is no different from the coolies worked from the 17th to 19th century in European colonies in the Americas, such as Peru, Cuba, Costa Rica, Mexico, US, etc. 

Coolies usually worked in cotton or sugar plantations, or on the US transcontinental railroad. The timing of coolie system’s emergence was interestingly right after African slavery’s abolition. Cheap labor is always needed, if not under raw slavery, then it’s under sugarcoated unfair “contract” signed between coolies and their “employers”. 

Similar to the “recruitment fee” the foreign labor has to pay to work in Qatar now, coolies a hundred years ago were loaned money from the farm owners, and had to keep working on a fixed salary before the loan was paid off, and their freedom to travel freely in the country earned. This means the coolies sold themselves to the the farm owners when they provided labor. 

Exploitation never ends. Slavery, coolie, forced labor, industrial zone workers…. Just a name change, and we thought it only existed in history.

the story about qatar, the workers, and the world cup is secondary. there’s no clearer evidence of this than the fact that johnny doesn’t actually start talking about conditions in qatar until 18 minutes into the video! that’s nearly 2/3rds of the way in. most everything to that point is about johnny’s struggle to get inside. to go himself. to find someone on the inside. etc. he spends as much time talking about himself (if not more) as he does concerned with the workers and what they face. 

the interviews. the reports from human rights organizations. the insider footage. these are the things we want to see…not a montage of johnny at his standing desk for the 40th time. less journalist. more journalism.

I have been a Johnny Harris subscriber for a long time and I have been watching all of your videos as soon as they come out. Most of the time i'm waiting for your uploads. Good work.

But I have somethings to say about this video. I have been living in Qatar for 20 years (and i'm not a Qatari). Lot of things in this video are exaggerated and some are wrong. Like, I have been to industrial area a lot of time, and it's not a 'restricted' place. Yes, it's seperated from town, and it does not have the luxury of the town and the worker work in difficult conditions, but where in the world does construction workers work in a/c. The stadium and some outdoor places are air conditioned, but how can a construction site be air conditioned. It's not just hot in Qatar, the whole Arabia is hot, and all construction workers in the Arab work in the hot weather. How did Dubai construct the whole city? Do you think Emiratis build Dubai and Abudhabi? No, it's the Indians, Bangalese and Nepalese. 

I'm not justifiying. Just saying that, just because Qatar is getting a lot of attention these days, lots of criticism is obviously expected. Especially when it's a small Islamic country with such huge wealth. More workers have died building stadiums in Brazil than in Qatar, and no one ever talked about that.

The Doha metro map that Johnny showed is wrong⚠️. I don't know where Johnny got that map from. But the gold line, which Johnny said was "never build" was actually the second line to open to the public, right after the red line. I know because I have travelled in that.

And bachelors are allowed in to reside in the city, and many do. It's just that most construction companies provide residence in the industrial area. It's true that bachelors are not allowed in the family area, but the whole Doha city is not family residence. Again, I know because I have been there and I have seen.

I agree that the gap between the luxury of the citizens and the worker conditions is one of the most in the world. But it's the same in all rich countries. A lot of people from Indian Subcontinent work here in Qatar and most of them are happy.
This exploitation of workers is sadly very common in the gulf region. I personally witnessed Africans and Indonesians house maids get physically and sexually abused by their employers.
Now lets hope the world's "attentions" to this tragic working condition,etc doesn't end up as the qatar world cup end.

The only attractive part of living in gulf states is better quality of life (if you get a good enough job) and less taxes.

Hi Johnny,

I subscribed to your channel, almost watched all of your videos and I must say your are the first western journalist  I know who can shed a light on things from different angles and perspectives to deliver a profound but holistic approach to subjects. I love you man. Keep up the good work.

Regarding this video though. I heard the 6.5K deaths of workers is not true and deaths are way less. Hope you can fact-check that. And if it's untrue, what caused it? I have the feeling that, besides the issues Qatar has, there is also lot of propaganda going on here with Qatar.

To put it simply in 2017, there was a Saudi-led blockade against Qatar. Saudi Arabia and the UAE (secretly supported by the USA) were upset that Qatar was starting to go a bit rogue. Qatar was moving closer to Iran and away from Western influence and of course that’s a big no no in the region. They announced that they would be cutting all ties with each other, even economically, and the excuse was that Qatar was supporting terrorism (which is a lie because Saudi and the UAE also supports terrorism haha). So both sides started going absolutely haywire with the propaganda. The Emiratis payed over 700k to PR firms to publish bad stories about Qatar, the Saudis and the UAE also filed a complaint to FIFA against Qatar to cancel the World Cup there. Qatar owns Al Jazeera and so naturally they also started airing negative stories about Saudi and the UAE. If you remember the hysteria about Jamal Khashoggi you can see that they also succeeded in damaging Saudi’s reputation. The blockade only ended last year and even though they’re pretending to be friendly with each other, there is still no Saudi ambassador in Qatar and relations are still strained. Basically, this controversy surrounding the World Cup is a remnant of the Gulf crisis/blockade. Of course this doesn’t mean it’s a lie. Jamal Khashoggi was murdered by MBS and Qatar treats is works poorly, there’s no denying any of this, but it’s still a PR battle.

The white collar workers live a comfortable life there, better than they have in India.    From these white collar workers, mostly engineers, I've heard plenty of stories just like this one. I used to work for Qatar Airways. Even to it's considered to be the best job for expats there, it's not. The uniform is made of natural wool. During the summer it gets up to 50C. You're not allowed to take off your jacket (the same you wear in winter in Zurich) when in public: sometimes we had to wait under the sun for 15-20 minutes until being picked up (stocking, wool skirt and jacket, hat, blouse with 3/4, and a camisole underneath. 
You're not allowed to stay out of accommodation in between 4am and 7am, you have minimum rest (you're not allowed to go out of the hotel/accommodation 12 hours prior to your pick up time). They never follow the rule of flying hours per month (if they need to make you fly exceeding hours and for you to be "legal" - they will). You're not allowed to have visitors who are not Qatar airways employees or don't hold Qatari ID (it's been forbidden to stay in a hotel with your parents/close relatives if they visit you in Doha, and they're forbidden to come see your place). If you want to get married you have to ask the company first, if you want to live with your spouse - you have to ask for a permission (mostly they decline; allow only for crew). To leave the country for vacation - you have to ask permission from the ministry of foreign affairs (mostly 24 hours before your planned trip). And much more

@Brad S and do those Haitian workers have their passports taken away on arrival so that they cannot leave?

@William Chamberlain I actually like your response, and I feel like I would enjoy you as a debate partner. However…you still didn’t answer my question. How would you do it differently? Should employers pay employees more than necessary solely because they can afford it? 

I’m currently in the Dominican Republic, where the locals import cheap labor from Haiti. They pack them into these big trucks and put them to work in extremely hot temperatures. 

It sucks and I wouldn’t want to do that type of work for that type of money, but these Haitians leave home for this opportunity and it allows them to send money home to support their families. No matter how crappy the job is, it’s still an upgrade to finding work in Haiti. 

It’s easy to crap on something, but it doesn’t mean much unless you pose a better solution. Do you support free market dynamics? Capitalism?

If you were the head of Qatar, how would you handle sourcing manual laborers? They already fully subsidize their citizens, so they have no motivation to get their hands dirty.

Sorry if I sounded insensitive, but I am puzzled by the 'debt trap', i. e. the recruitment fees the workers have to pay. In most of the jobs that I work, if I have to relocate, I am expecting a sign in bonus or that my employer paid the relocation costs.
In white collar jobs, the employer company will often paid a hefty fee to the recruiting company. I never heard of the worker paying anything (usually the recruiting company cover the interview costs). 
Is it common in India / Nepal / Myanmar that the worker paid a recruiting fee to the recruiting company ? If yes, how does the 'recruiting company' justify it?
Why does the workers accept this system, despite this being a signal that the job has horrible conditions ? I am guessing because the money seems to good to pass on in theory, and lack of information about the reality.

The hefty recruitment fee is very common everywhere in the world for foreign workers, even in places with better wage and working conditions. It's usually the local agents looking to make profit, because the rich countries or companies needing those labor don't actually want to make it hard for cheap labor to come. There's a documentary from BBC about seasonal Indonesian plantation workers in the UK and the company said it's also a problem for them and they would like to eliminate it, and they offer returning workers to work directly for them so they don't have to pay the agents. Their wage for the first season there is basically used to pay back the debt, and then they return the next year to earn actual money.

Would it be unreasonable to think that the World Cup organizers should to some degree be held responsible for choosing a country where these kinds of labour abuses have been well-known for a fairly long time? I'm not even a highly informed person, but I've heard of this kind of thing happening to support the construction of cities like Doha and Dubai for years, and let's face it, the governments of the Arabian peninsula (among other places, yes) have never shied away from using slavery and exploiting severely disadvantaged workers to fuel their obscene wealth. This is well known, and yet the World Cup has chosen to condone and perpetuate these abuses through its decision to let Qatar host the games. I believe they have blood on their hands. I also think boycotting the games would be a reasonable gesture for sports fans to make, but I wouldn't expect that.

A final point: I know this is far from the only problematic development project tied to big sports. I live near Vancouver, and remember when the Olympics came to the city, they shipped a huge amount of the homeless people (with one-way tickets) over to Vancouver Island so that the tourists coming to enjoy the games wouldn't have to suffer through seeing the "filth" living on the streets. No country is beyond reproach.

Actually, the more I think about it, I think ticket-buyers also need to accept a certain measure of responsibility, for helping fund an organization that supports slavery and flagrant labour abuses knowingly. Buying a ticket is also an act of condoning and perpetuating these evils.

The zoning thing is not unreasonable. I mean let's try to see things from a different perspective: university towns that attract lots of foreign students, for example, would similiarly zone student mass housing (like dormintory buildings) separately from local residential areas. There are lots of good reasons for doing this - transport infrastructure planning, considerations regarding the distribution of essential services etc.  

More importantly are the demographic considerations: this video is framing the zoning as a racist thing, but anyone who's being honest will admit that an influx of many single men (and I mean single as in they might be married back home but don't have any partners locally) is likely to cause an increase in certain types of economic activity, including vice (alcohol consumption, visiting prostitutes, etc). Any responsible government will want to limit the potential spillover of such activities into existing residential areas where family units reside. Do this type of zoning in, say, an American mining town where the workers are Americans from other states and nobody would bat an eyelid. 

I won't defend the witholding of pay and curbs on free movement though, those are definitely dehumanizing.

@Pratham Sharma Yes, but firstly illegal doesn't mean it doesn't exist. I'd bet there's a sizeable black market of alcohol and sexual services in Qatar - these things exist in many gulf countries. 

Secondly even if the presence of alcohol and prostitution is small initially, there's the likelihood that they will increase as the demand for them increase together due to the influx of bachelors. Zoning the workers close together makes logistical sense for this reason.
But all the things you related with bachleors are illegal in Qatar.

The 'kafala' system is barbaric yet a common norm for migrant workers in the gulf countries. Let alone getting their salaries paid on time, their passports are often confiscated by the employers who often torture and abuse them. It's far worse for women workers who are often raped and even killed. 200 Bangladeshi female workers died in Saudi Arabia alone between 2016 and 2020.

For a system in the western media which calls out countries like India on human rights, it always intrigued me how come modern-day slavery in the rich oil wealthy countries in the middle east always seems to miss their eyes. I am sure it is a co-incidence :)

For a media machinery that has humiliated India for 80% of Indians' religious beliefs leading to regional beef bans (which are still portrayed by this system as national), there seem to be no major setbacks for countries with less than 20% of the population being actual citizens that enforce the religious beliefs that barely allow any women's rights, ban alcohol for everyone including foreigners in the world cup, and execute secret missions on killing journalists on foreign lands, in addition to what we saw in this video. And Al-Jazeera has literally done it all, and defended all the hypocritical restrictions and is still hailed as a reliable news source in the west.

As an Indian, I have always known what happens to my fellow Indians in these countries. The Indian government can't do much as foreign currency inflow for a net importer like us and maintaining good relations for oil is more important. So I applaud your bold reporting and decision to post this at this time, as well as the Nepalese reporter for showing a lot of what everyone in South Asia already knows about slavery.

Your video is absolutely bullshit, you should know that 95% of the employment in India, Bangladesh, and Pakistan is bonded, you have to sign 5-10 year-long bonds that are legally enforceable and if you break them, you can go to jail or be forced to pay 100s of thousands of dollars, 

If the living conditions in Qatar were so shit, we wouldn't be flocking there in droves, we do it because the median wage in India is 110 USD nominal (770 USD in PPP), rent, food, healthcare, and electricity are free (rural areas, subsistence farming), however to become rich without having any education, you have to get some 220-330 dollars per month, after that, you will live like a king in any rural area; however, this is impossible in India without becoming a doctor, lawyer, or an engineer, so people usually go to Qatar where they get 300-500 dollars per month with free food and free accommodation (shared beds and shitty food), they then send the money to their family in India, and their children can finally attend a school (most schools in India are private schools, the fees is something like 40-50 dollars per year but many people can't afford them) and your family can live a good life in their village.


Yes, it's not the best thing, you are still a bonded labourer in Qatar, but it's unarguable that your family will live a good life back in India

Bangali here 🖐️. We have had a name for these labor recruiters for years: Adam-bepari (Merchants of Human). They were more popular and rampant during the nineties, and primary pull being jobs in Malaysia, Qatar, Dubai, Oman. There were lots of scamming involved. These recruiters don't usually recruit people directly and instead have local middlemen doing the actual convincing and hiring, and people actually bribe these middleman to enlist. Even with all the possible abuse and exploitation in a foreign land, you have to understand that the earnings and living conditions are still better than what our poorer class is used to. In local soils, they'd be doing double the work for half the pay anyway. Often, these hiring slots are actually deemed valuable enough to be political currency, even traded to local leadership as tokens or boons.

I grew up in Dubai and lived there 35 years.

To not notice it happening means that you really were not paying attention or more realistically...you didn't care about it much as long as you were comfortable.

Most people know, and most turn a blind eye.
Some people help when they can, but have to be quite careful not to draw too much attention to these issues.

It's sort of an easy way to end up being jailed or deported and banned for life...or worse.

Let's just say that you are 'encouraged' to keep your mouth shut while you are living and working in those countries. In particular if it's anything that damages the country's image.

It's the same in pretty much every Gulf country really. Some more strict than others...but in general people have the sense not to bite the hand that feeds.

I would also like to add that this is pretty well known in the countries that send labourers to that region.
Philippines, Pakistan, India, Bangladesh etc...those countries know what's up.
The governments of those countries don't really do much to protect the human rights of their citizens either.

At the end of the day, no one is forced to go there and I know several there who were NOT privileged...worked hard for many years and became very successful as a result.

You cannot have a one sided knee jerk reaction to this because you suddenly woke up to what was right under your nose your entire life and you instantly grew a conscience.

Did you honestly think the buildings of Doha grew out of the desert by magic?

I'm not saying it's right and a good way to treat people...but the fact is...they go there because it seems like a better alternative to life in their own country.

I notice India has improved a lot in the last decade or so in many ways at an encouraging pace. Still much more to do...but it's at least heading in a reasonably good direction.

For many Indians the Gulf isn't as attractive as it once used to be... And that's a good thing.

Here in Russia we have similar "hostage labour" practices. With a few differences. First, employers here are not racist so they're taking Russians from poor regions and give them "jobs" in other parts of the country (yes, they also use debt, paperwork and isolation as a mean of stripping people away from their rights and ability to leave). 10 years ago I did some work in the industrial area of Doha for a few weeks as part of an internship (long story). Safe to say I got some strange looks as a young, white European man in that area. I didn't get to explore the area much as I was strictly forbidden from leaving the warehouse I was working in, and was driven directly there and back every day by a company driver. I did have some interesting conversations and banter with the other workers though, most of which were Sri Lankan, Nepalese, and Filipino. 

It was also Ramadan at the time, so it was at the height of summer, meaning it was extremely hot. There was no functioning AC, and I had to sneak away to drink water or smoke a cigarette. Only worked half days though during Ramadan. 

It was an interesting few weeks, and I wish I could divulge more but my memory of this time is very hazy.

Harris I am from Bangladesh here. The tradition of migrant workers going to the middle east started in the 70s. I personally know many of them who  went there to make a fortune and make a good use of the strong currency of Qatar. The work is  hard,  the conditions and right as workers are worst. But they do get paid better than the local economy. But there are several places like in Saudi and others, they treat migrant workers with relatively good rights. For being one of the LDCs, there are no better options than to work on those harsh conditions. In a way,  the  remittance they send is one of the significant pillars of the country's economy. I do not know why our officials are not looking into this matter for a long term solution.

Talk to anyone that served in the US military, and they will tell you that exploiting outside labor is a tradition in the middle east. The ship I served on saved a slave ship that was heading from Ethiopia to Yemen. In the end, when we returned them to Ethiopia, we are pretty sure they were killed by their own government (a warlord-type system).

Their ship lost its engine and floated out in the Gulf of Aden for days without food or water. Many people onboard died. We got a report of a ship DIW, which is why we responded to help them.

I’m sorry but this has got to be one of the most naive, insulated and out of touch comments I have read recently and I will call you out on it.

1) You said you worked in several industries over 10 years there in Qatar and you and other expats you have met are happy. Did you start off as a migrant worker who paid a recruitment fee to go to Qatar and had your wages withheld and had to work in 50C and live in crap accommodation? Were any of the happy expats you mentioned being used as labour and being exploited to build infrastructure for the World Cup? The point is there’s no point referencing the happiness of expats who are clearly NOT the migrant workers that this issue is about.

2) I agree (to an extent) the “people of Qatar” are not doing anything “wrong”. But the Qatari Government has set up a system that allows the exploiting and abuse of migrant workers. E.g. “Recruitment fee” to go and work in Qatar, Not paying wages. These are very WRONG!! Qatar has enough money to bribe corrupt FIFA officials in the millions but no money to cover the BS “Recruitment fee” and withholding wages?? That is baffling.

3) Your comment about “workers were already in deep financial difficulties” and “living in the worst situation in their home” insinuates that this gives a free pass for the Qatar government to exploit and abuse migrant workers - is this correct? I’m not sure all were in the most dire of dire situations as you would like to believe either. Those people might not have had the same opportunities to make money as others in their home country so if an opportunity to make money for their families in an HONEST manner comes along, can you blame them for taking it? The difference is they are forced into a system that takes advantage of their situation. Even if they came from dire situations they seen to be better quality human beings than those running the show in Qatar.
